description.narrative:
The Goal of the Capfish/FOSTER project is to improve the socio-economic conditions of the fishing communities and environmental sustainability of the (Western) Tonle Sap Biosphere Reserve (TSBR) through community-centered interventions reaching over 200000 women, men and children in Cambodia. The Capfish/FOSTER Project led by Oxfam and 14 partners has 3 Objectives: 1)Fishing communities in the Tonle Sap have increased access to safe water supply, hygiene and sanitation services2) Vulnerable and poor girls and boys are provided with increased availability and accessibility to education and can successfully transition through school 3) Fishing communities in the Tonle Sap have developed sustainable alternative livelihoods. In order to respond to the urgent need for fishing communities to diversify their livelihoods and reduce environmental pressures to the TSBR, the project will undertake a series of interventions aimed at creating sustainable livelihood and employment opportunities in ecotourism, solar energy, and sustainable agriculture,fish processing and forestry.
Sansom Mlup Prey (SMP) develops sustainable, organic, and wildlife-friendly agricultural systems inrural communities in Cambodia by supporting meaningful agricultural livelihoods that protect over 50 Vulnerable wildlife Species and preserves 500,000 hectares of forest. In the Capfish/FOSTER Project SMP will implement activities related to sustainable rice farming in compliance with the Sustainable Rice Platform (SRP), the world's first standard for sustainable rice cultivation to diversify the livelihood of communities around the Tonle Sap Biosphere Region (TSBR). SMP will provide specific training on Women's Economic Empowerment (WEE) in SRP farming to enable women to enjoy a larger share of the value they produce. In addition, training will be provided in , marketing, branding, value addition, and market expansion to increase the sustainability and profitability of the livelihood strategies for Community Fisheries.

participating-org.narrative: SANSOM MLUP PREY (SMP) was formed in 2009 to promote and market wildlife-friendly products grown or crafted in communities located in protected areas of Cambodia. It is working to link wildlife conservation to improving livelihoods of villagers limited by the constraints of living in a remote area with little opportunity to expand operations and access market. In Cambodia, protected areas either contain, or are used by, long-established local communities who are very poor and heavily dependent upon the forest and surrounding habitat for their livelihoods. Agricultural-based livelihood development is limited by low prices offered by the few traders that visit. This provides little incentive for communities to improve agricultural efficiency, and many households are trapped in debt cycles. With growing human population, the pressure on land resources is increasing, leading to widespread forest clearance in key conservation areas and conflicts between communities and government agencies responsible for environmental protection. Successful wildlife and habitat conservation depends on engaging them through tools that directly link local economic and social development to conservation. SMP buys products from village marketing networks (VMN), whose membersare voluntarily recruited from farmers who agree to abide by conservation rules and regulations, including wildlife protection and maintenance of land-use boundaries. These rules andregulations are previously concurred to by the government and the community. They offer preferential prices to community members, and target the poorer farmers, who are often not food secure and rely on forest resources. SMP plays a role as the villages connection to markets not typically accessible to producers from remoteprovinces and ensures that conservation activities are being adhered to, which enables rewards to be shared at the end of each season. SMP works in partnership with different organizations, including local and international NGOs, government ministries, andlocal villages.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to a sustainable livelihood
